docs.lead_paragraph: More than a month after Food Emporium supermarkets agreed to pay $3 million to deliverymen who earned far less than the $5.15-an-hour minimum wage, dozens of deliverymen at another chain, Gristede's, continue to be paid less than $2.50 an hour. Alexis Ondongo, a deliveryman at the Gristede's supermarket at 75th Street and Second Avenue, said he receives a $75 check each week for 60 hours of work and then averages $100 in tips on top of that.

headline.main: Pay Case Does Not Help All of City's Deliverymen

docs.abstract: Article contends that more than month after Food Emporium supermarkets agreed to pay $3 million to deliverymen who earned far less than $5.15-an-hour minimum wage, dozens of deliverymen at another chain, Gristede's, continue to be paid less than $2.50 an hour; spokesman for Gristede's says it is not responsible since deliverymen are paid by Great American Delivery Company; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., the nation's largest health insurer, is in preliminary talks to try to settle its share of a host of lawsuits that attack core marketing and operating practices of the H.M.O. industry, according to lawyers on both sides. The talks in New York have intensified in the last 10 days as the two sides await a ruling by a federal judge in Miami on whether some of the most important cases can proceed. But lawyers said the insurer and the plaintiffs remained far apart in the settlement efforts.

headline.main: Lawyers Say Aetna Trying To Settle Suit

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc is in preliminary talks to try to settle its share of host of lawsuits that attack core marketing and operating practices of health maintenance organization industry; talks have intensified in last 10 days as two sides await ruling by federal judge in Miami on whether some of most important cases can proceed; Aetna lawyers say insurer and plaintiffs remain far apart in settlement efforts (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed state budget for the fiscal year that begins April 1 is the seventh spending plan he has issued as governor. In his budget, he proposed overall spending of $83.6 billion, a figure that includes federal aid for programs like welfare and Medicaid. If enacted, the budget would represent a 5.3 percent increase in state spending. The portion to be raised by the state totals $57.4 billion, up 4.9 percent. Of that, the general fund, which includes most tax revenue, would rise 3.6 percent, to $41.3 billion, though the definition of the fund has changed over the years to artificially limit its growth.

headline.main: Highlights of the Pataki Budget Plan

docs.lead_paragraph: The gene-sequencing machines that unraveled the human genome were nearly the size of refrigerators and cost $300,000 apiece. Richard T. Daly's sequencers fit easily on a desk -- and he is giving them away. The reason is that Mr. Daly wants to move gene sequencing from research laboratories into daily medical practice. The company he heads, Visible Genetics, has developed a test to sequence genes of the virus that causes AIDS, providing information to help doctors choose which of the 15 or so available drugs will work best against a particular patient's infection.

headline.main: When Gene Sequencing Becomes a Fact of Life; Test Helps Doctors Find Best AIDS Drugs

docs.abstract: Visible Genetics develops test to sequence genes of virus that causes AIDS, providing information to help doctors choose which of 15 or so available drugs will work best against particular patient's infection; Applied Biosystems, leading manufacturer of sequencing machines, is also developing such tests; graph; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move aimed at allowing more disabled people to enter the work force, Gov. George E. Pataki today reversed his position of last year by saying he would include $90 million in his budget so they can earn significantly more without losing Medicaid insurance. The governor also said he would urge the Legislature to raise the income limits on Medicaid insurance for women diagnosed with breast or cervical cancer, giving several hundred more low-income women coverage than in the past.

headline.main: Pataki Backs Easing Limits For Disabled on Medicaid

docs.abstract: New York State Gov George Pataki, in move aimed at allowing more disabled people to enter work force, reverses his position of last year by saying he would include $90 million in his budget so they can earn significantly more without losing Medicaid insurance; Pataki says he will also urge Legislature to raise income limits on Medicaid insurance for women diagnosed with breast or cervical cancer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After eight years as secretary of health and human services, Donna E. Shalala has a little advice for the Republicans who will soon replace her and thereby inherit vast responsibilities for the nation's health and welfare. Medicare reform, as promised by the Bush administration, ''is not so easy,'' Dr. Shalala said with a rueful laugh.

headline.main: Before Leaving Health Agency, Shalala Offers a Little Advice on a Big Job

docs.abstract: Donna E Shalala, secretary of health and human services during Clinton administration, says Medicare reform promised by Bush administration is 'not so easy'; recalls that efforts to set up demonstration projects to explore more market-driven Medicare were routinely opposed by local health care providers in alliance with their congressmen; says her greatest regret on leaving office is failure to put health care for low-income working families, and child care for them, in place before welfare reform; photo (M)
